(Same as JS 190 4)
This course satisfies the new Religion major requirement:- Theme, Region. 
Whether it's a debate on masks and vaccines, humanitarian crisis on the border, or censoring books, the Holocaust is an ever-present point of reference in American public discourse. In this seminar, we will explore how the genocide of European Jews 'which took place far from the United States and involved few Americans' came to play such central role in American consciousness. 
We will ask how Holocaust memory relates to reckoning with legacies of slavery, anti-black racism, and settler colonialism. Our topics will include Anne Frank and 'Americanization' of the Holocaust; debates that surrounded the creation of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, DC; the Holocaust's impact on the U.S. responses to other genocides; and the contentious issue of comparisons. We will also examine the relationship between white nationalism, neo-Nazism, antisemitism, and Holocaust denial. 
For our analysis, we will use film and TV, media coverage, politicians' speeches, museum displays, and monuments. We will utilize Emory's special collections relating to the Holocaust and explore relevant sites of memory in Atlanta
